publisher.title: The Map of Early Modern London

availability.p: Copyright held by The Map of Early Modern London on behalf of the contributors.

licence.p: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International License.

availability.p: Further details of licences are available from our Licences page. For more information, contact the project director, Janelle Jenstad, for specific information on the availability and licensing of content found in files on this site.

sourceDesc.p: Original transcription from EEBO-TCP, STC 25175; new transcription by Joey Takeda. DEEP 721. File checked and standardized by Chase Templet, following the 2018 transcription guidelines.

abstract.p: Commemorative pageant book prepared for the inauguration of Sir John Gore as Lord Mayor of London in 1624. Pageants coordinated by John Webster on behalf of the Worshipful Company of the Merchant Taylors. Book printed by Nicholas Okes. Diplomatic transcription prepared by the MoEML Team. See https://mapoflondon.uvic.ca/MONU1.htm for full credits and editorial procedures.

prefixDef.p: Most MoEML documents, or significant fragments with xml:id attributes, can be addressed using the mol: prefix and accessed through the web application with their id + .xml.
The molagas prefix points to the shape representation of a location on MoEMLâ€™s OpenLayers3-based rendering of the Agas Map.

Links to page-images in the Chadwyck-Healey Early English Books Online (EEBO) repository. Note that this is a subscription service, and may not be accessible to those accessing it from locations outside member institutions.
Links to page-images in the English Broadside Ballad Archive (EBBA).
The mdt (MoEML Document Type) prefix used on catRef/target points to a central taxonomy in the includes file.

The mdtlist (MoEML Document Type listing) prefix used in linking attributes points to a listings page constructed from a category in the central MDT taxonomy in the includes file. There are two variants, one with the plain xml:id of the category, meaning all documents in the specified category, and one with the suffix _subcategories, meaning all subcategories of the category.
The molgls (MoEML gloss) prefix used on term/corresp points to a a glossary entry in the GLOSS1.xml file.

This molvariant prefix is used on ref/target attributes during automated generation of gazetteer index files. It points to an element in the generated variant spellings listing file which lists all documents which contain a particular spelling variant for a location.

This molajax prefix is used on ref/target attributes during the static build process, to specify links which point to MoEML resources which should not be loaded into the source page during standalone processing; instead, these should be turned into links to the XML source documents, and at HTML page load time, these should be turned into AJAX calls. This is to handle the scenario in which a page such as an A-Z index of the whole site would end up containing virtually the whole site inside itself.
The molstow prefix is used on facs attributes to link to the HCMC verison of the Stow facsimiles. Usually the first group is the year (1633) and then last is the image number (0001).

editorialDecl.p: These digital editions are diplomatic transcriptions. Our goal has been to provide clean, readable TEI transcriptions of all the extant mayoral shows from 1585 to 1639. Because this corpus has never before been made available in one place, we provide XML base texts that other scholars can repurpose according to our Creative Commons Licence.

MoEML transcriptions of the mayoral shows are based intially on the EEBO-TCP transcriptions. A MoEML research assistant or contributing scholar has carefully checked the TCP transcription at least once against the EEBO images (and sometimes against the Early English Books I microfilms when the film is clearer). We silently correct errors in TCP transcriptions and fill in many of the gaps left by TCP transcribers. When we make surmises about characters or supply characters in places where the text has been cropped, damaged, overinked, or underinked, we record our supplied values using supplied. The transcription is checked again by another MoEML research assistant, and finally by the Project Director or Assistant Project Director. Users may report transcription errors via the Send Feedback link on each page.

We treat title pages, dedications, and prefaces as front matter, encoded with the front element. We treat speeches, narrative descriptions, and interpretations as the body of the text, encoded with the body element. We treat colophons and concluding statements, including the word Finis, as back matter, encoded with the back element.

normalization.p: Our practice has been to preserve most of the typographical, orthographical, and compositorial features of the original text. We use CSS styling to describe the peculiarities of font and justification. We also include links to the page images on EEBO; users who subscribe to EEBO may thus view the pages at any point and judge our transcription thereof for themselves.

Our encoders follow these rules for preserving or regularizing the text:
Textual Component
Rule
Long Å¿
TCP transcriptions do not preserve the long Å¿. We have restored the long Å¿ through a series of find-and-replace functions based on typical early modern printing house habits, followed by a careful human checking against the digital images of the original.
Capitalization
We preserve the capitalization of the source, including the second upper-case letter after a woodblock dropped capital.
Italicization
We preserve the italicization of words by tagging them with a hi element with a style value of font-style: italic;. We consider italicization to be a bibliographic code rather than a linguistic code.
Interchangeable Characters
We retain the interchangeable u/v and i/j and the use of vv for w. These are not marked up with any encoding.
Ligatures
We retain the vowel digraphs using the appropriate Unicode characters (e.g., Ã¦). Typographical ligatures (e.g., ï¬‚) have been silently expanded.
Nasal Tildes
We retain the nasal tilde over vowels (e.g., Ãµ) using the appropriate Unicode characters.
Spacing Within Lines
MoEML closes up extra spaces between words and punctuation marks. However, we retain the spacing in authorial initials, such as A. M. (for Anthony Munday). We have added a single space after a comma when the comma has been used to separate two words.
Lineation
MoEML preserves the line breaks in verse sections and the line wrapping in prose sections of mayoral shows. Prose line breaks have been encoded with a self-closing lb element. All line breaks in verse are produced by the use of l elements contained by lg elements.
Hyphenation
MoEML transcriptions of mayoral shows preserve the hyphenation of words, both within and at the end of lines.
Quotation Marks
All quotation marks are retained in the text and are represented by appropriate Unicode characters. We do not use the quote element for quotations in primary-source texts. MoEML practice calls for curly apostrophes and straight double quotation marks in both transcriptions and born-digital texts.

interpretation.p: We have interpreted and encoded toponyms, names, and dates. The encoding of toponyms requires some research to point the toponym to the right location file (and thence to the map), but the relative stability of the processional route has meant that we have high confidence in our encoding of toponyms in the mayoral shows. When our encoding has veered into interpretation, such as in our decision to encode abstract nouns as allegorical characters even when it is not completely clear that the abstraction is embodied by an actor, we have encoded with the goal of building analytical capacity into our texts, such as the capacity for users to search for characters like Time across the corpus of mayoral shows. For our treatment of early modern dates, see our encoding instructions at Encode a Date. Other than toponyms, names, and dates, we have undertaken no interpretative encoding.

encodingDesc.p: Our editorial and encoding practices are documented in detail in the Praxis section of our website.

revisionDesc.change: Deleted all rendition elements in header.
Added xml:ids to pb elements using utilities/add_sig_ids_to_shows.xsl.
Changed calendar value from "julian" to "julianSic" using XSLT.
Standardized respStmts for JENS1, MCFI1, and HOLM3 and added TAKE1 as Junior Programmer.
Added XInclude for listPrefixDef in the header.
Pasted in MOEML transcription into document.
Eliminated superfluous catRef elements from the header.
Put change elements inside revisionDesc into the correct (latest first) order.
Added profileDesc containing document type information expressed in catRef elements.

interreÅ¿ted

p.style: text-align: right; margin-right: 6rem; font-style:italic; font-size: 135%; padding-bottom: 1.5rem;

div.p: To your LordÅ¿hip in all duty,

signed.style: text-align:right; margin-right: 6rem; display:block; padding-bottom: 2rem; font-variant:small-caps; word-spacing: .5rem; letter-spacing: .15rem; font-size: 115%;

fw.style: text-align: right; margin-right: 6rem; font-size: 115%; padding-bottom: 10rem; font-size: 100%;

div.head:
Monuments of
Honor.
div.p:
I Could in this my Preface (by
as great light of Learning as
any formerly imployed, in
this Å¿eruice) can attaine, to de
liuer to You the Original and
cauÅ¿e of all Tryumphes, their
exceÅ¿Å¿iue coÅ¿t in the Time of
the Romans: I could likewiÅ¿e
with Å¿o Noble Amplification make a Å¿uruey of the
worth, and glory of the Triumphs of the precedent
times in this Honorable City of London: That
were my work of a bigger bulke, they Å¿hold remaine
to all PoÅ¿terity: but both my Pen, and ability this
way are confinâ€™d in too narrow a Circle: Nor haue
I Å¿pace enough in this Å¿o Å¿hort a Volume to expreÅ¿Å¿e
onely with rough lines, and a f aint Å¿hadow (as the
Painters phraÅ¿e is) FirÅ¿t the great care and alacrity
of the right WorÅ¿hipful the MaÅ¿ter and Wardens,
and the reÅ¿t of the Å¿elected and InduÅ¿trious Com

fw.style: text-align: right; margin-right: 14rem; letter-spacing: .25rem; font-size: 100%;
text-align: right; margin-right: 8rem; margin-top: -1.2rem; font-size: 100%;
font-style: italic; font-size: 150%; padding-bottom: .5rem; text-align: center;

div.p:
mitees; both for the curious and iudging election
of the Subiect, for the preÅ¿ent Spectacles; and next
that the working or mechanicke part of it might
be anÅ¿werable to the Invention: Leauing therefore
theÅ¿e worthy Gentlemen to the embraces, and
thankes of the right Honorable and worthy Pretor;
and my Å¿elfe vnder the Å¿haddow of their CreÅ¿t,
(which is a Å¿afe one) for â€™tis the Holy Lambe in the
Sunne-beames: I do preÅ¿ent to all modeÅ¿t and in
different Iudges theÅ¿e my preÅ¿ent endeavours.

I faÅ¿hioned for the more amplefying the Å¿hew
vpon the water two Eminent Spectacles, in maner
of a Sea-Triumph. The firÅ¿t furniÅ¿ht with fower
PerÅ¿ons; In the front Oceanus and Thetis, behind
them, ThemeÅ¿is and Medway: the two riuers on
whom the Lord Mayor extends his power, as farre
as from Stanes to RocheÅ¿ter. The other Å¿hew is of
a faire TerreÅ¿tiall Globe, Circled about in conue
nient Seates, with Å¿eauen of our moÅ¿t famous Na
uigators: as, Sr. Francis Drake, Sr. Iohn Haukins,
Sr. Martine FurbiÅ¿her, Sr. Humfery Gilbert, Cap
taine Thomas CauendiÅ¿h, Captaine ChriÅ¿topher
Carlile, and Captaine Iohn Dauis. The conceite
of this Deuice to be, that in regard the two Riuers
pay due Tribut of waters to the Seas. Oceanus in
gratefull recompence returnes the memory of
theÅ¿e Å¿eauen worthy Captaines, who haue made
England Å¿o famous in remoteÅ¿t partes of the
world. TheÅ¿e two Å¿pectacles, at my Lord Maiors
taking water at the Three Cranes, aproaching my

fw.style: text-align: right; margin-right: 6rem; font-size: 100%;
font-style: italic; font-size: 150%; padding-bottom: .5rem; text-align: center;

div.p:
Lords Barge: after a peale of Sea-thunder from the
other Å¿ide the water; theÅ¿e Å¿peeches betweene
Oceanus and Thetis follow.
div.label: Oceanus and Thetis.
Thetis.

lg.l: WHat braue Sea MuÅ¿icke bids vs Welcome, harke!
Sure this is Venice, and the day Saint Marke,
In which the Duke and Senats, their courÅ¿e hold
To wed our Empire with a Ring of Gold.

div.label: Oceanus.

lg.l: No Thetis yâ€™are miÅ¿taken, we are led
With infinite delight from the Lands head:
In ken of goodly Å¿hipping and yon bridge,
Venice had neare the like Å¿uruey that ridge,
Of Å¿tately buildings which the riuer Hem,
And grace the Å¿iluer Å¿treame, as the Å¿treame them:
That beautious Å¿eate is London Å¿o much famâ€™d,
Where any Nauigable Sea is namâ€™d;
And in that bottome Eminent Marchants placâ€™t,
As rich, and venturous as euer gracâ€™t,
Venice or Europe theÅ¿e two Riuers heare,
Our followers may tell you where we are;
This ThameÅ¿is, that Mid-way who are Å¿ent,
To you most worthy Pretor to preÅ¿ent,
Acknowledgment of duty neare Å¿hall err,
From Stanes vnto the Ancient RocheÅ¿ter;
And now to grace their Tryumph in reÅ¿pect,
TheÅ¿e pay vs tribute, we are pleaÅ¿d to Å¿elect

fw.style: text-align: right; font-style: italic; margin-right: 5rem; font-size: 100%;
font-style: italic; font-size: 150%; padding-bottom: .5rem; text-align: center;

lg.l: Seuen worthy Nauigators out by name,
Seated beneath this Globe; whoÅ¿e ample fame
In the remoteÅ¿t part aâ€™ the earth is found,
And Å¿ome of them haue circled the Globe round:
TheÅ¿e you obÅ¿erue are liuing in your eye,
And Å¿o they ought, for worthy men neare dye:
Drake, Hawkins, FurbiÅ¿her, Gilbert, braue Knights,
That brought home gold, and honor from Å¿ea fights,
CandiÅ¿h, Carlile, and Dauis, and to theÅ¿e,
So many worthies I could adde at Seas,
Of this bold Nation, it would enuy Å¿trike,
I thâ€™ reÅ¿t athâ€™ World, who cannot Å¿hew the like;
Tis action valews honor as the flint,
Looke blacke and feeles like ice, yet from withinâ€™t,
Their are Å¿trooke Å¿parkes which to the darkeÅ¿t nights,
Yeeld quicke and percing food for Å¿euerall lights.

div.label: Thetis.

lg.l: You haue quickned well my memory, and now
Of this your gratefull Tryumph I allow,
Honor lookes cleare and Å¿preads her beames at large,
From the graue Senate Å¿eated in that Barge,
Rich Lading Å¿well your bottomes, a bleÅ¿t Gale,
Follow your ventures that they neuer faile;
And may you liue Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿iuely to weare,
The Ioy of this day, each man his whole yeare.

div.p:
This Shew hauing tendred this Å¿eruice to my
Lord vppon the Water, is after to be conueyed a
Shore, and in conuenient place employd for ador

fw.style: text-align: right; margin-right: 7.5rem; font-size: 100%;
font-style: italic; font-size: 150%; padding-bottom: .5rem; text-align: center;

div.p:
ning the reÅ¿t of the Triumph. After my Lord Maiors
landing, and comming paÅ¿t Paules Chaine, there
firÅ¿t attends for his Honor in Pauls Church-yarde,
a beautifull Spectacle, called the Temple of Honor,
the Pillars of which are bound about with RoÅ¿es,
and other beautifull Flowers, which Å¿hoot vp to the
adorning of the Kings MaieÅ¿ties Armes on the top
of the Temple.

In the higheÅ¿t Å¿eate a PerÅ¿on repreÅ¿enting Troy
nouant or the City, in throned in rich Habilaments,
beneath her as admiring her peace and felicity, Å¿it
fiue eminent Cities, as Antwerpe, Paris, Rome, Venice
and ConÅ¿tantinople: vnder theÅ¿e Å¿it fiue famous
Schollers and Poets of this our Kingdome, as Sir
Ieffery Chaucer, the learned Gower, the excellent
Iohn Lidgate, the Å¿harpe witted Sr. Thomas Moore,
and laÅ¿t as worthy both Souldier and Scholler, Sir
Phillip Sidney, theÅ¿e being Celebrators of honor,
and the perÅ¿eruers both of the names of men, and
memories of Cities aboue, to poÅ¿terity.

I preÅ¿ent riding afore this Temple, Henry de
Royall, the firÅ¿t Pilgrime or Gatherer of quartridge
for this Company; and Iohn of YeackÅ¿ley, King Ed
ward the thirds Pavillion maker, who purchaÅ¿t our
Hall in the Å¿ixt yeare of the aforeÅ¿ayd Kings gouern
ment: TheÅ¿e liued in Edward the firÅ¿ts time like
wiÅ¿e, (in the Å¿ixt of whoÅ¿e Raigne, this Company
was confirmed a Guild or Corporation by the
name of Taylors, and Linnin Armores, with power
to chooÅ¿e a MaiÅ¿ter and Wardens at MidÅ¿omer)

fw.style: text-align: center; font-size: 100%;
text-align: right; margin-top: -1.2rem; margin-right: 7rem; font-size: 100%;
font-style: italic; font-size: 150%; padding-bottom: .5rem; text-align: center;

div.p:
theÅ¿e are decently habited and hooded according
to the ancient manner: My Lord is heere Å¿aluted
with two Speeches, firÅ¿t by Troynouant in theÅ¿e
lines following.
div.label: The Å¿peech of Troynouant.

lg.l: HIÅ¿tory, Truth, and Vertue Å¿eeke by name,
To celebrate the Merchant-Taylors fame,
That Henry de Royall, this wee call
Worthy Iohn YeackÅ¿ley purchaÅ¿t firÅ¿t their Hall;
And thus from low beginnings their oft-Å¿prings
Societies claime Brother-hoods of Kings.
I Troynovant placâ€™t eminent in the eye
Of theÅ¿e admire at my felicity::
Fiue Cities, Antwerpe and the Å¿pacious Paris,
Rome, Venice, and the Turkes Metropilis:
Beneath theÅ¿e, fiue learned Poets worthy men,
Who do eternize braue acts by their pen;
Chaucer, Gower, Lidgate, Moore and for our time
Sr. Phillip Sidney, glory of our clime,
TheÅ¿e beyond death a fame to Monarckes giue,
And theÅ¿e make Cities and Societies liue.

div.label:
The next deliuered by him, repreÅ¿ents Sir
Phillip Sidney.

lg.l: TO Honor by our Wrightings Worthy men,
Flowes as a duty from a iudging pen,
And when we are emploid in Å¿uch Å¿weet praiÅ¿e,
Bees Å¿warme and leaue their honey on our bayes:
Euermore MuÅ¿ically VerÅ¿es runne,
When the lothâ€™d vaine of flattery they Å¿hun.

fw.style: text-align: right; margin-right: 6rem; font-style: italic; font-size: 100%;
font-style: italic; font-size: 150%; padding-bottom: .5rem; text-align: center;

lg.l: Suruey moÅ¿t Noble Pretor what Å¿ucceedes,
Vertue low bred aÅ¿piring to high deedes.

div.p:
TheÅ¿e paÅ¿Å¿ing on, in the next place, my Lord is
incountred with the perÅ¿on of S. Iohn Hawkwood in
compleate Armour, his plume and Feather for his
HorÅ¿es Å¿hafforne of the Companies colours, white
and Watchet: this worthy Knight, did moÅ¿t wor
thy Å¿eruice, in the time of Edward the third in
France, after Å¿erued as Generall.

Diuers Princes of Italy, went to the Holy-land,
and in his returne backe, dyed at Florence, and there
lyes buried with a faire Monument ouer him: This
worthy Gentleman was Free of our Company; and
thus I prepare him to giue my Lord entertainment.
div.label: Sir Iohn Hawkwoods Speech.

lg.l: MY birth was meane, yet my deÅ¿eruings grew
To eminence, and in France a high pitch flew,
From a poore common Souldier I attaind,
The Å¿tile of Captaine, and then Knight-hood gaind;
Serud the Blacke Prince in France in all his warrs;
Then went tâ€™the Holy-land, thence brought my Å¿cars.
And wearied body which no danger feard.
To Florence where it nobly lyes Inteerd,
There Sir Iohn Hawkewoods memory doth liue,
And to the Merchant-Taylors fame doth giue.

div.p: After him followes a Triumphant Chariot with the

fw.style: letter-spacing: .25rem; text-align: center;
text-align: right; margin-right: 5rem; margin-top: -1.2rem; font-size: 100%;
font-style: italic; font-size: 150%; padding-bottom: .5rem; text-align: center;

div.p:
Armes of the Merchant-Taylors, colored and guilt
in Å¿eueral places of it, and ouer it, there is Å¿upported
for a Cannopy, a rich and very Å¿patious Pauillion,
coloured CrimÅ¿on, with a Lyon PaÅ¿Å¿ant: this is
drawne with fower horÅ¿es, (for Porters would haue
made it moue tottering and Improperly.) In the
Chariot I place for the honor of the Company (of
which Records remaine in the Hall:) Eight Famous
Kings of this Land, that haue bin free of this Wor
Å¿hipfull Company.

FirÅ¿t the Victorious Edward the Third, that firÅ¿t
quartered the Armes of France with England, next
the Munificent Richard the Second, that kept Ten-
ThouÅ¿and daily in his Court in CheckrÃ³ule, By him
the Graue and diÅ¿creet Henry the Fourth, in the
next Chayres the Scourge and Terrour of France,
Henry the Fifth, and by him his religious, though
vnfortunate Sonne, Henry the Å¿ixt: the two next
Chayres are Å¿upplied with the PerÅ¿ons of the Ama
rous and PerÅ¿onable Edward the Fourth (for Å¿o
Phillip Commineus, and Sir Thomas Moore deÅ¿cribe
him) the other with the bad man, but the good
King, Richard the third, for Å¿o the Lawes he made
in his Å¿hort Gouernment doe IlluÅ¿trate him; But
laÅ¿tly in the moÅ¿t Eminent part of the Chariot I
place the wiÅ¿e and politique Henry the Seauenth,
houlding the Charter by which the Company was
Improued from the Title of Linin-Armorers into
the name of MaÅ¿ter and Wardens of Merchant-
Taylors of Saint Iohn BaptiÅ¿t. The Chayres of theÅ¿e

fw.style: text-align: right; margin-right: 5rem; font-size: 100%;
font-style: italic; font-size: 150%; padding-bottom: .5rem; text-align: center;

div.p:
Kings that were of the HouÅ¿e of LancaÅ¿ter are gar
niÅ¿ht with artificiall Red RoÅ¿es, the reÅ¿t with white,
but the Vniter of the deuiÅ¿ion and houÅ¿es, Henry
the Seauenth, both with White and Red, from
whence his Royall MaieÅ¿ty how raigning tooke his
Motto: for one peice of his Coyne, Henricus roÅ¿as
regna Iacobus.

The Å¿peaker in this Pageant is Edward the third,
the laÅ¿t Line of his Å¿peech is repeated by all the reÅ¿t
in the Chariot.
div.label: Edward the Third.

lg.l: VIew whence the Merchanttaylors honor Å¿prings
From this moÅ¿t Royall Conuenticle of Kings:
Eight that SucceÅ¿Å¿iuely wore Englands Crowne
Held it a Å¿peciall honor, and renowne:
(The Society was Å¿o worthy, and Å¿o good)
Tâ€™vnite themÅ¿elues into their Brotherhood.
Thus Time, and InduÅ¿try attaine the priÅ¿e,
As Seas from Brookes, as brookes from Hillocks riÅ¿e,
Let all good men this Å¿entence oft repeate,
By vnity the Å¿malleÅ¿t things grow great.

div.label: The Kings.
div.l: By vnity the Å¿malleÅ¿t things grow great.
div.p:
And this repetition was proper, for it is the Com
panies Motto: Concordia paruÃ¦res creÅ¿cunt.

After this Pageant rides Queene Anne, wife to
Richard the Å¿econd, free likewiÅ¿e of this Company,

fw.style: letter-spacing: .25rem; text-align: center; font-size: 100%;
text-align: right; margin-right: 5.5rem; margin-top: -1.2rem; font-size: 100%;
font-style: italic; font-size: 150%; padding-bottom: .5rem; text-align: center;

div.p:
nor let it Å¿eeme Å¿trange, for beÅ¿ides her, there were
two DutcheÅ¿Å¿e, fiue CounteÅ¿Å¿es, and two Barron
neÅ¿Å¿es free of this Society, Å¿euenteene Princes and
Dukes, one Arch-biÅ¿hop, one and thirty Earles,
(beÅ¿ides thoÅ¿e made with Noble Prince) Henry, one
Vicount, twenty foure BiÅ¿hops, Å¿ixty Å¿ix Barons,
Å¿euen Abbotts, Å¿euen prior; or Å¿ubprior, and with
Prince Henry in the yeare 1607. the Duke of Linox,
the Earles of Nottingham, Suffolke, Arundel, Oxford,
WorceÅ¿ter, Pembrooke, EÅ¿Å¿ex, Northampton, SaliÅ¿bury,
Montgomery, the Earle of Perth, Vicount Cran
borne: Barons, the Lord Euers, HunÅ¿den, Hayes,
Borley, Mr. Howard, Mr. Sheffield, Sir Iohn Harrin
ton, Sir Thomas Chaliner, beÅ¿ides States of the
Low-Countries, and Sir Noel Caroone their Legier
EmbaÅ¿Å¿adour.

And in regard our Company are Å¿tild Brethren
of the Fraternity of St. Iohn BaptiÅ¿t, and that the
ancient Knights of St. Iohn of IeruÅ¿alem, (to which
now demoliÅ¿ht HouÅ¿e in St. Iohns Streete, our
Company then vÅ¿ing to go to offer, it is recorded
Henry the Å¿euenth then accompaning them, gaue
our Mr. the vpper hand,) becauÅ¿e theÅ¿e Knights, I
Å¿ay, were inÅ¿tituted to Å¿ecure the way for Pilgrimes;
in the deÅ¿ert, I preÅ¿ent therefore two of the Wor
thieÅ¿t Brothers of this Society of St. Iohn BaptiÅ¿t I
can find out in HyÅ¿tory. The firÅ¿t Amade le Graunde,
by whoÅ¿e ayde Rhodes was recouered from the
Turkes, and the order of Anuntiade or Salutati
on inÅ¿tituted with that of foure letters FERT, Å¿ig

fw.style: text-align: right; margin-right: 5rem; font-size: 100%;
font-style: italic; font-size: 150%; padding-bottom: .5rem; text-align: center;

div.p:
nifying, Fortitudo Eius Rhodum Tenuit; and the o
ther of MounÅ¿ieur Iean Valet, who defended Malta
from the Turkes inuation, and expeld them from
that impregnable Key of ChriÅ¿tendome this
Å¿tild, Great MaiÅ¿ter of Malta, that Gouernour of
Rhodes.

Next I bring our two Sea Tryumphs, and af
ter that, the Shippe called the Holy-Lambe, which
brings hanging in her Shrowdes the Golden-
Fleece, the conceite of this being that God is
the Guide and Protector of all ProÅ¿perous Ven
tures.

To Å¿econd this, follow the two beaÅ¿ts, the Lyon
and Cammell proper to the Armes of the Com
pany; on the Camell rides a Turke, Å¿uch as vÅ¿e to
Trauaile with Carauans, and one the Lyon a
Moore or wild Numidian.

The fourth eminent Pagiant, I call the Monu
ment of Charity and Learning, this faÅ¿hioned like
a beautifull Garden with all kind of flowers, at the
foure Corners, foure artificiall Bird Cages, with
variety of Birds in them: this for the beauty of the
Flowers, and melody of the Birds, to repreÅ¿ent a
Spring in Winter: in the middeÅ¿t of the Garden,
vnder one Elme-tree, Å¿its the famous and worthy
Patriot Sir Thomas White; who had a dreame that
hee Å¿hould build a Colledge where two bodies
of an Elme Å¿prang from one roote, and beeing
inÅ¿pired to it by God, firÅ¿t rod to Cambridge,
to Å¿ee if he could find any Å¿uch, Failing of it there,

fw.style: text-align: right; margin-right: 6rem; font-size: 100%;
font-style: italic; font-size: 150%; padding-bottom: .5rem; text-align: center;

div.p:
went to Oxford and Å¿urueighing all the grounds, in
and neere the VniuerÅ¿ity, at laÅ¿t in GloÅ¿ter-Hall-
garden, he found one that Å¿omewhat reÅ¿embled it,
vpon which he reÅ¿olued to endow it with larger re
uenew, and to increaÅ¿e the foundation, hauing
Å¿et men at worke vpon it, and riding one day out at
the North-Gate at Oxford, he Å¿pied on his right
hand the Å¿elfe Å¿ame Elme had bin figurd him in his
dreame, wherevpon he giues oâ€™re his former pur
poÅ¿e, of Å¿o amply inlarging GloÅ¿ter-Hall (yet
not without a large exhibition to it) purchaÅ¿es the
ground where the Elme Å¿tood: and in the Å¿ame
place built the Colledge of Saint Iohn BaptiÅ¿t, and
to this day the Elme growes in the Garden, care
fully preÅ¿erued; as beeing vnder God a motiue to
their worthy foundation.

This I haue heard Fellowes of the HouÅ¿e of ap
proued credit, and no way Å¿uperÅ¿titiouÅ¿ly giuen,
affirme to haue bin deliuered from man to man,
Å¿ince the firÅ¿t building of it, and that Sir Thomas
White inuiting the Abbot of OÅ¿nye to dinner in the
aforeÅ¿ayd Hall, In the Abbots preÅ¿ence, and the
hearing of diuers other graue perÅ¿ons affirmâ€™d by
Gods InÅ¿piration in the former receited maner, he
built and endowed the Colledge.

This relation is Å¿omwhat with the largeÅ¿t, only
to giue you better light of the figure: the cheife per
Å¿on in this is, Sir Thomas White, Å¿itting in his Emi
nent Habit of Lord Maior, on the one hand Å¿its
Charity with a Pellican on her head, on the other

fw.style: text-align: right; font-style:italic; margin-right: 6rem; font-size: 100%;
fw.name: Learning

fw.style: font-style: italic; font-size: 150%; padding-bottom: .5rem; text-align: center;

div.p:
Learning with a booke in one hand, and a Lawrel
Wreath in the other, behind him is the Colledge
of St. Iohn BaptiÅ¿t in Oxford exactly modeld, two
Cornets which for more pleaÅ¿ure anÅ¿were one and
another interchangably, and round about the
Pageant Å¿it twelue of the foure and twentie Cities,
(for more would haue ouer-burthened it) to which
this worthy Gentleman hath beene a charitable
Benefactor when my Lord approaches to the front
of this peece: Learning humbles her Å¿elfe to him in
theÅ¿e enÅ¿uing verÅ¿es.
div.label: The Speech of Learning.

lg.l: TO expreÅ¿Å¿e what happineÅ¿Å¿e the Country yeilds,
The Poets faignâ€™d Heauen in thâ€™Elizian fields;
We figure here a Garden, freÅ¿h and new,
In which the chiefeÅ¿t of our bleÅ¿Å¿ings grew:
This worthy Patriot here, Sr. Thomas White,
Whilst he was liuing had a dreame one night,
He had built a Colledge and giuen liuing tooâ€™t,
Where two Elme-bodies Å¿prang vp from on root;
And as he dreamt, moÅ¿t certaine tis he found,
The Elme neare Oxford, and vpon that Ground,
Built Saint Iohns Colledge, Truth can testifie
His merrit, whilÅ¿t his Faith and Charity
Was the true compaÅ¿Å¿e, meaÅ¿urâ€™d euery part,
And tooke the latitude of his ChriÅ¿tian heart;
Faith kept the center, Charity walkt this round,
Vntill a true circumference was found;

fw.style: text-align: center; font-style: normal; font-size: 100%;
text-align: right; font-style: italic; margin-right: 6rem; margin-top: -1.2rem; font-size: 100%;
font-style: italic; font-size: 150%; padding-bottom: .5rem; text-align: center;

lg.l: And may the ImpreÅ¿Å¿ion of this figure Å¿trike,
Each worthy Senator to do the like.

div.p:
The laÅ¿t, I call the Monument of Gratitude, which
thus dilates it Å¿elfe.

Vppon an Artificiall Rocke, Å¿et with mother of
Pearle; and Å¿uch other precious Å¿tones, as are found
in quarries, are placed foure curious Paramids
charged with the Princes Armes, the three Fea
thers, which by day yeeld a glorious Å¿hew, and
by night a more goodly, for they haue lights in
them, that at Å¿uch time as my Lord Maior returnes
from Pauls, Å¿hall make certaine ouals and Å¿quares,
reÅ¿emble pretious Å¿tones, the Rocke expreÅ¿Å¿es the
riches of the Kingdome Prince Henry was borne
Heire to, the Piramids, which are Monuments for
the Dead, that hee is deceaÅ¿ed: on the top of this
reÅ¿ts halfe a CeleÅ¿tiall Globe, in the middeÅ¿t of this
hangs the Holy Lambe in the Sunbeames, on
either Å¿ide of theÅ¿e, an Angell, vpon a pedeÅ¿tall
of gold Å¿tands the figure of Prince Henry with his
Coronet, George and Garter; in his left hand hee
holds a Circklet or CrimÅ¿on Veluet, charged with
foure Holy Lambes, Å¿uch as our Company chooÅ¿e
MaÅ¿ters with; in Å¿euerall Cants beneath Å¿its, firÅ¿t
MagiÅ¿tracy tending a Bee Hiue, to expreÅ¿Å¿e his
Grauety in Youth, and forward induÅ¿try to haue
proued an abÅ¿olute Gouernour: Next Liberality,
by her a Dromedary Å¿hewing his Å¿peed and alacrety
in gratifying his Followers: Nauigation with a
Iacobs Staffe and CompaÅ¿Å¿e, expreÅ¿Å¿ing that his de

fw.style: text-align: right; margin-right: 5rem; font-size: 100%;
font-style: italic; font-size: 150%; padding-bottom: .5rem; text-align: center;

div.p:
Å¿ire that his reading that way, might in time grow
to the practicke & building, to that purpoÅ¿e one of
the goodlieÅ¿t Ships was euer launcht in the Riuer:
in the next Vnanimity with a Chaplet of Lyllies, in
her lap a Å¿heafe of Arrowes, Å¿hewing he loued No
bility, and Communalty with an intire heart. Next
InduÅ¿try on a hill where Antes are whording vp
Corne, expreÅ¿Å¿ing his forward inclination to all
Noble exerciÅ¿e: Next ChaÅ¿tity, by her a Vnicorne,
Å¿hewing it is guide to all other vertues, and cleares
the Fountaine head from all poyÅ¿on: IuÅ¿tice with
her properties: Then Obedience, by her an Elephant
the Å¿trongeÅ¿t BeaÅ¿t, but moÅ¿t obÅ¿eruant to man of
any Creature: Then Peace Å¿leeping vpon a Canon,
alluding to the eternall Peace he now poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿es: For
titude a Pillar in one hand, a Serpent wreathâ€™d a
bout the other, to expect his height of minde, and
the expectation of an vndaunted reÅ¿olution. TheÅ¿e
twelue thus Å¿eated, I figure Loyalty as well Å¿worne

my Lord Maiors comming from Pauls, and going
downe Wood-Å¿treete, Amade le Graunde deliuers this
Speech vnto him.
div.label: The Speech of Amade le Graunde.

lg.l: OF all the Triumphs which your eye has viewâ€™d
This the fayre Monument of Gratitud;
This cheefly Å¿hould your eye, and eare Imploy
That was of al your Brother-hood the Ioy,
Worthy Prince Henry fames best preÅ¿ident,
Cald to a higher Court of Parliament,

fw.style: text-align: center; letter-spacing: .25rem; font-size: 100%;
text-align: right; font-style: italic; margin-top: -1.2rem; margin-right: 5rem; font-size: 100%;
font-style: italic; font-size: 150%; padding-bottom: .5rem; text-align: center;

lg.l: In his full Å¿trength of Youth and height of blood,
And which Crownd all, when he was truely good:
On Vertue, and on Worth he Å¿till was throwing
MoÅ¿t bounteous Å¿hewers, where erâ€™e he found them (growing,
He neuer did diÅ¿guiÅ¿e his wayes by Art
But Å¿hooted his intents vnto his hart,
And louâ€™d to do good, more for goodneÅ¿Å¿e Å¿ake,
Then any retribution man could make.
Such was this Prince, Å¿uch are the noble hearts;
who when they dye, yet dye not in all parts:
But from the Integrety of a Braue mind,
Leaue a moÅ¿t Cleere and Eminent Fame behind.
Thus hath this Iewell not quite loÅ¿t his Ray,
Only caÅ¿â€™d vp â€™gainÅ¿t a more glorious day.
And beeâ€™t rememberd that our Company
Haue not forgot him who ought nerâ€™e to dye:
Yet, wherfore Å¿hould our Å¿orrow giue him dead,
When a new PhnÃ¦ix Å¿prings vp in his Å¿tead:
That as he Å¿econds him in euery grace,
May Å¿econd him in Brother-hood, and place.
Good reÅ¿t my Lord, Integrity that keeps
The Å¿afeÅ¿t Watch and breeds the Å¿oundeÅ¿t Å¿leeps.
Make the laÅ¿t day of this your houlding Å¿eate,
Ioyfull as this; or rather more compleate.

div.p:
I could, a more curious and Elaborate way haue expreÅ¿t my Å¿elfe
in theÅ¿e my endeauors, but to haue bin rather too teadious in my
Speeches, or too weighty, might haue troubled my Noble Lord,
and puÅ¿led the vnderÅ¿tanding of the Common People; Å¿uffice it, I
hope â€™tis well, and if it pleaÅ¿e his LordÅ¿hip, and my Worthy Im
ployers, I am amply Å¿atiÅ¿fied.
